exchanges.assistant:
**Dinner with your parents—genuinely good:** Your dad asked about the new job and seemed genuinely interested, your mom was beaming, and they were supportive without being overbearing or "I told you so" about it. You said it felt different than you expected, and I think what's different is that you showed up as yourself—not hiding, not performing, just sharing what's actually happening in your life. And they met you there. Your mom gets to see you moving forward after watching you struggle, and your dad engaged in a way that doesn't always happen. That's connection, real connection, and it sounds like it made you feel seen in a way that mattered.

**New job nerves—the good kind:** You start in two weeks and you're nervous, but it's butterflies, not catastrophizing. That's such a different flavor than the dread you've been carrying about work for months. You've been reading about the organization, you genuinely care about what they do, and you've never felt that way about a job before. That excitement mixed with nerves? That's what it feels like to be moving toward something instead of just running away from something. Let yourself feel that. It's allowed to be both exciting and scary at the same time.

**Noticing the rest of your life—apartment's a mess, haven't seen friends, living on stress and coffee:** Now that work isn't consuming all your mental energy, you're seeing the other stuff you've been neglecting—your space, your friendships, your actual life outside of survival mode. You said it sounds like a good problem to have but also it's overwhelming to think about fixing everything at once. Here's the thing: you don't have to fix everything at once. You've been in crisis mode for six months. Your apartment being a mess, not seeing friends—that's not a moral failure, that's what happens when you're treading water just to keep your head above the surface. Now you've got room to breathe, and yeah, there's some cleanup to do. But you don't have to do it all this week.

Pick one small thing. Maybe it's tidying one room this weekend. Maybe it's texting a friend you haven't seen in a while and saying "want to grab coffee sometime?" Maybe it's cooking one real meal instead of living on coffee and stress. Just one thing that feels manageable, not the whole life overhaul at once. You've just made two massive changes—new job, debt plan—and you're about to start a role that actually matters to you. Give yourself permission to ease into the rest of it instead of sprinting toward the next project. The mess isn't going anywhere. Your friends will still be there. You've got time.
